content: First, I know little about Yahoo and cannot directly assist. However, I will share this bit of information and hope it helps: Yahoo requires a different password when using an email client and requires OAUTH2 authentication. This URL may assist: https://help.yahoo.com/kb/SLN15241.html
creator: davidsk

content:
The short answer is no.

Thunderbird stores all of your information on the local machine not on some cloud somewhere. It uses your account information to access your account with the various providers, but it does not share any information about your various accounts with anyone except the mail provider that they need to be used with to communicate with to get and send your mail.

Having said that if you place your Thunderbird profile on a location on the local machine that Microsoft backup to their online drive product then I guess they can ostensibly have access to everything in your backup. It sort of depends on how much you backup, how much you trust Microsoft what they say they are unable to access your encrypted information without you signing in.
creator: MattAuSupport

creator: davito9w

content:
what mail provider and how frequently is Thunderbird set to check mails in account settings.

Lots of extrapolating going on in my head here, but I have seen issues with some providers that have strict intervals between checking mail (like 15 minutes) where the provider appears to use the total connection attempts from an IP address in that 15 minute window so the send account connects, then the first again and everything falls over because the connection is refused. Retry just adds another connection attempt and the issue gets worse, not better.

Personally I have something like that happening with outlook.com, on startup when every account hits the server to authenticate I get issues with outlook refusing connections but if I ignore the initial failures everything settles within about 15 minutes all of the account get their mail.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
The provider is a french provider named Bouygues. The interval is currently set to 10 minutes.

I thought of an interval issue. Indeed, it seems significant that the problem occurs on the provider with 2 accounts.

But:

  1. I would expect this to trigger issues rather on the second account. Well, assuming TB calls the providers in same order as the accounts, but maybe TB does not use this order.
  2. This should resolve itself in a few minutes, just like you. Days seems too long. But maybe the issue does not last for days, maybe it just re-triggers itself.
  3. When I generated a log for the wrong account, I disabled the other accounts in order to get a cleaner log. The issue stayed. Then I disabled all accounts except the second account from the same provider, in order to get a clean log of a successful connection to this provider, and the connection was successful as usual.

Anyhow, I just set the interval to 16 minutes and I unchecked "Check for new messages at startup" for the second account. If this does not work, I will try 2 things separately:

  1. Swap the 2 first accounts
  2. Disable the "bad" account and recreate it

BTW, I have those logs, I see where they start differing, but I am unable to go any further.
creator: davito9w

content: If you end up creating a new account, just set it to default in the Account Settings and drag it to the top of the list. That will make it appear at the top of the Folder pane.
creator: siffemoz

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content: If running Windows, enter %appdataS% in search box on task bar and press enter. This should bring you to appdata\roaming folder. look for a folder named thunderbird.

content:
Why are you leaving outlook? I ask because for Thunderbird to import successfully Outlook has to be installed and fully functional if it had been giving issues then there may be corruption in the outlook store that prevents the import

What version of outlook to you have installed? When you import are you selecting everything? Do you get a different outcome if you select to import just mail or address books?
